title: Add encryption methods
body:
## Current Behavior

Geth does not currently provide any encryption methods

## Wanted Behavior

[EIP 1024](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/1098) describes cross-client encrypt/decrypt methods that enable public key encryption across ethereum clients, for example a sender could encrypt data with their MetaMask wallet and the receiver could decrypt it with geth.  MetaMask has already implemented [this](https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-sig-util), Parity version is in progress,  and it would be awesome to have a geth implementation as well. The underlying crypto library being used is NaCl elliptical curve encryption library, the curve being used is curve25519.

Here is the specification:

```const nacl = require('tweetnacl')

/**
* Returns user's public Encryption key derived from privateKey Ethereum key
* @param {Account} receiver - The Ethereum account that will be recieving/decrypting the data
*/
web3.eth.getEncryptionPublicKey(receiver.address) { /* implementation */ }

/**
* Encrypts plain data.
* @param {string} encryptionPublicKey - The encryption public key of the receiver 
* @param {string} version - A unique string identifying the encryption strategy.
* @param {Bytes} data - The data to encrypt
* @param {Number} padding - The number of characters to left-pad the data with (optional)
* @param {Function} callback - The function to call back when decryption is complete.
*/ 
web3.eth.encrypt(encryptionPublicKey, version, data, padding, callback) { /* implementation */ }

/**
* Decrypts some encrypted data.
* @param {Account} receiver - The account that will decrypt the message
* @param {Object} encryptedData - Encrypted payload, the data to decrypt
* @param {Function} callback - The function to call back when decryption is complete.
*/
web3.eth.decrypt = function decrypt (recievier.privatekey, encryptedData, callback) { /* implementation */ }
```

##Definition of Done

You have successfully completed this bounty, when:

1. A developer can request an accounts encryption public key
2. A developer can encrypt any arbitrary data with using elliptical curve25519
3. A developer can decrypt any arbitrary data encrypted with their accounts encryption public key
4. These methods are compatible with MetaMasks encryption methods listed (here)[https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-sig-util]

Issue Status: 1. **Open** 2. Started 3. Submitted 4. Done

<hr>

__Work has been started__.


These users each claimed they can complete the work by 2 months, 1 week ago.
Please review their action plans below:


**1) [bakaoh](https://gitcoin.co/profile/bakaoh) has been approved to start work.**

I will base on your code at https://github.com/topealabi/eth-sig-util/blob/master/index.js and implement in Go. I will try to finish in a week

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/ethereum/go-ethereum/17816/1340).


**2) [cpurta](https://gitcoin.co/profile/cpurta) has applied to start work _(Funders only: [approve worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/ethereum/go-ethereum/17816/1340?mutate_worker_action=approve&worker=cpurta) | [reject worker](https://gitcoin.co/issue/ethereum/go-ethereum/17816/1340?mutate_worker_action=reject&worker=cpurta))_.**

Looks pretty straight forward in adding the those functions to the ethclient package and writing the tests for those. Looks like Geth currently does not support curve25519 so I am curious if it would be acceptable to find a package to perform the crypto. Or if that will need to be implemented from scratch and added to the crypto package and then called from there. 

If accepted I should be able to have the functionality stubbed out within about a day. Tests can also be stubbed out until the crypto question is addressed. If the elliptic curve crypto needs to be written from scratch that will take me a few days to implement and test and then be used by the new RPC methods. Overall I think that I can have this near completed within a weeks time.

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/ethereum/go-ethereum/17816/1340).
@topealabi -- i implemented it in Golang here https://github.com/bakaoh/eip1024 please review it so i can add those into geth and create PR

Hi, this LGTM. Now, while we have this library sent by the contributor, it is key for us to be able to use it in go-ethereum, as an RPC method.

For this task to be completed, it is only needed for the methods to be exposed, and of course write a little test inside geth (that's what the dev team is going to ask for the changes to be included inside `master`)

Exposing methods in geth is not that hard, here is an example in a fork we are working:

https://github.com/MetaMask/go-ethereum/blob/9eb464b44f059c3b8d1337d7a5f5f8e38697b4b3/eth/api_slicer.go#L44

Also. You may want to include your additional dependencies using this guide, so, with the command `make geth`, the builder is able to actually compile the fork: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Developers'-Guide#managing-vendored-dependencies

I'll add my note from the PR here too. This feature doesn't really fit with go-ethereum for the following reasons:

The proposed (JavaScript) API is a string-based wrapper around NaCl. The Ethereum blockchain doesn't use curve25519 for anything and there is no tooling for this curve in the codebase so far. Supposed we'd offer it anyway, where should it go? The (now closed) PR added it to ethclient where it doesn't belong because ethclient is a client for the RPC API. Should it be on the server side then? Not really because these functions don't need server-side state, it's a pure computation. Would you send your private key to a server only to have it decrypt something with that key for you?

If you must have that string-based API in Go the best option is to put it in a separate library. @bakaoh has already done this and should claim that bounty for it. I have no idea how GitCoin works, does he get the bounty if I close this issue?

@fjl @bakaoh @folsen @christianlundkvist @danfinlay @hermanjunge 

The goal of these methods is to enable end-to-end secure communication between clients. Because signing verifies the sender of a message and encryption verifies the receiver of a message we believe that these two methods should live together, or near each other.

As a developer If encryption methods are not readily available I may be motivated to roll my own,
which may be less secure and also incompatible with other clients like Parity or Metamask. 

If we agree that cross client encryption is important, where is the best place to put these methods in order to encourage developers to use them?
